articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud and Other Charges
articles.snippet: The founder of the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, who was released on a $250 million bond, returned to New York to appear in court on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The founder of the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, who was released on a $250 million bond, returned to New York to appear in court on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two weeks after he was released by a Manhattan judge on a $250 million bond and ordered to stay with his parents in Palo Alto, Calif., Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced cryptocurrency executive, returned to New York and pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges that he engaged in widespread fraud, paving the way for a possible trial.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Weiser, David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Speaker Fight Reveals a Divided and Disoriented House Majority
articles.snippet: In failing to coalesce around Kevin McCarthy for speaker, Republicans showcased divisions that portend real difficulties in governing.
articles.abstract: In failing to coalesce around Kevin McCarthy for speaker, Republicans showcased divisions that portend real difficulties in governing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow for the latest on the battle to choose a speaker in the House of Representatives.

articles.headline: Need an Onion? These Indian Apps Will Deliver It in Minutes.
articles.snippet: Fueled by billions of dollars in investments, Indian companies are rushing to cut delivery prices and wait times, relying on an army of low-paid, harried drivers.
articles.abstract: Fueled by billions of dollars in investments, Indian companies are rushing to cut delivery prices and wait times, relying on an army of low-paid, harried drivers.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall, Karan Deep Singh and Atul Loke

articles.headline: McCarthy Flounders as G.O.P. Rebellion Paralyzes the House for a Second Day
articles.snippet: The House continued a historic floor showdown — the first in a century — prompted by the Republican leader’s failure to secure a majority to become speaker.
articles.abstract: The House continued a historic floor showdown — the first in a century — prompted by the Republican leader’s failure to secure a majority to become speaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow for the latest on the battle to choose a speaker in the House of Representatives.

articles.headline: Why Are Energy Prices So High? Some Experts Blame Deregulation.
articles.snippet: California and the 34 other states that have deregulated all or parts of their electricity system tend to have higher rates than the rest of the country.
articles.abstract: California and the 34 other states that have deregulated all or parts of their electricity system tend to have higher rates than the rest of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: When California, New York, Texas and other states began deregulating their electricity markets in the 1990s, officials promised that those changes would foster competition and make energy more affordable.

articles.headline: Supply Problems Hurt Auto Sales in 2022. Now Demand Is Weakening.
articles.snippet: A global semiconductor shortage is easing, which could allow carmakers to lift production this year. But higher interest rates could keep sales low.
articles.abstract: A global semiconductor shortage is easing, which could allow carmakers to lift production this year. But higher interest rates could keep sales low.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, sales of new cars and trucks fell to their lowest level in a decade because automakers could not make enough vehicles for consumers to buy. This year, sales are likely to remain soft, but for an entirely different reason — weakening demand.

articles.headline: Meta’s Ad Practices Ruled Illegal Under E.U. Law
articles.snippet: The decision is one of the most consequential issued under the E.U.’s landmark data-protection law and creates a new business headwind for the social media giant.
articles.abstract: The decision is one of the most consequential issued under the E.U.’s landmark data-protection law and creates a new business headwind for the social media giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Meta suffered a major defeat on Wednesday that could severely undercut its Facebook and Instagram advertising business after European Union regulators found it had illegally forced users to effectively accept personalized ads.
